et: Middle English {it}brer, brere,{/it} going back to Old English {it}brēr, brǣr,{/it} of uncertain origin

The noun {it}briar{/it} belongs to a small set of words in which Middle English {it}ę̄ {/it} has been raised to {it}ī,{/it} whence [ai] in present-day English. These words are all, with the exception of {it}briar,{/it} of French origin: {et_link|friar|friar}, {et_link|quire:1|quire:1}, {et_link|choir:1|choir:1}, {et_link|contrive|contrive}, {et_link|umpire:1|umpire:1}, {et_link|dice|die:2}. See hypothesized explanations of this change in E. J. Dobson, {it}English Pronunciation 1500-1700,{/it} 2nd edition, vol. 2, pp. 655-58.

et: short for {it}briar pipe,{/it} from {it}briar{/it} "wood of the heath plant {it}Erica arborea,{/it}" borrowed (with conformation to {et_link|briar:1|briar:1}) from French {it}bruyère{/it} "the heath plant {it}Erica arborea,{/it}" going back to Old French {it}bruiere, bruere{/it} "moorland covered with heath, the heath plant {it}Erica arborea,{/it}" going back to Vulgar Latin {it}*brūcāria,{/it} from {it}*brūcus{/it} "heath plant" (borrowed from Gaulish {it}*wroikos{/it}) + Latin {it}-āria{/it} {et_link|-ary:1|-ary:1} {ma}{mat|erica|}{/ma}

The meaning of the derivative {it}*brūcāria{/it} must initially have been "place covered with {it}*brūcus,{/it}" but early on in Old French it was applied to the plant itself. The simplex {it}*brūcus{/it} is attested as Old Occitan {it}bruc, bru, breu,{/it} Catalan {it}bruc,{/it} Upper Italian (Piedmont) {it}brü,{/it} (Milan) {it}brüg.{/it} A tenth-century botanical vocabulary (see {it}Corpus glossariorum Latinorum{/it} vol. 3, p. 587) has the gloss {it}brucus : ramnus{/it} [Greek {it}rhámnos{/it} "thorny shrub"]. The treatment of the diphthong ({it}*oi{/it} > {it}*ū{/it}) in the passage from Celtic to Vulgar Latin is idiosyncratic; it seems unlikely to have any connection to the monophthongization of {it}oe{/it} (> {it}ū{/it}) in classical Latin.
shortdef: a tobacco pipe made from a woody root outgrowth of a shrub-like Mediterranean heath (Erica arborea)
